title: Antigravity vs Neptune AI in 2025: Multi-Agent IDE vs MLOps Platform
metaDescription: Compare Antigravity's free multi-agent AI coding with Neptune's MLOps experiment tracking for 2025. See which tool fits your developer or data science workflow.
introduction:
The AI tool landscape in 2025 offers specialized solutions for distinct technical challenges. On one side, Antigravity has emerged as a groundbreaking force in developer tools, redefining AI-assisted coding with its unique multi-agent orchestration. Debuting at #1 in developer rankings, it promises to automate complex software projects through collaborative AI agents. On the other side, Neptune stands as a mature, purpose-built pillar of the MLOps ecosystem, designed to bring order and reproducibility to the chaotic process of machine learning experimentation, particularly for teams training large foundation models.

While both leverage advanced AI, their core missions diverge fundamentally. Antigravity is a proactive creation engine, integrating AI agents directly into the coding process to generate, test, and debug applications. Neptune is a reactive observation and management platform, built to meticulously log, compare, and query the metadata from AI/ML experiments run elsewhere. This comparison will dissect their pricing, features, and ideal use cases to help developers, data scientists, and engineering leaders choose the right tool for their 2025 projects.

Choosing between them is not about which tool is objectively better, but which problem you need to solve: accelerating code creation and web automation, or governing the machine learning lifecycle. This analysis will provide the clarity needed to make that critical decision.

sections.title: Overview
paragraphs: Antigravity is a revolutionary multi-agent AI code editor that transforms the software development process. It is built on VS Code and distinguishes itself by orchestrating multiple AI agents (using models like Gemini 3 Pro and Claude 4.5) to collaborate autonomously on complex coding tasks. Its integrated Chrome browser automation allows for live testing and design-to-code conversion, positioning it as an all-in-one IDE for modern, AI-driven development. Completely free during its preview, it targets individual developers and teams looking to drastically increase coding velocity and tackle ambitious projects.

Neptune is an enterprise-grade MLOps metadata store, a critical tool for teams engaged in machine learning and foundation model training. Its core function is to log, organize, and visualize every piece of metadata—metrics, parameters, artifacts, images—generated during the ML lifecycle. With deep integrations across frameworks like PyTorch, TensorFlow, and Hugging Face, Neptune provides a single source of truth for experiment tracking, model registry, and collaboration. It addresses the challenges of reproducibility, comparison, and governance in large-scale, distributed data science teams.

sections.title: Pricing Comparison
paragraphs:
The pricing models highlight the different target audiences and stages of each platform. Antigravity operates on a completely **free** model during its preview phase, with no announced tiered plans. This aggressive strategy aims for rapid user adoption and community building, lowering the barrier to zero for developers to experience cutting-edge multi-agent coding. Its long-term monetization strategy remains to be seen.

Neptune follows a **freemium** model, offering a free tier with limited storage and features suitable for individual practitioners or small projects. Its paid plans scale based on usage (storage, compute hours, users) and are designed for professional teams and enterprises. These plans unlock advanced features like role-based access control (RBAC), more projects, and priority support, reflecting its position as a business-critical MLOps infrastructure tool where reliability and collaboration features justify the cost.

sections.title: Features & Capabilities
paragraphs:
**Antigravity's** feature set is centered on AI-assisted creation and automation: Its flagship **multi-agent orchestration** is unique, enabling AI agents to specialize and work together. **Integrated Chrome browser automation** allows for seamless testing and web scraping within the IDE. It functions as a **full IDE** with Git integration, collaborative editing, and recently added voice interaction. Support for the latest LLMs and 3D graphics points to its focus on front-end and full-stack development.

**Neptune's** features are built for observation, management, and governance: Its **flexible metadata logging** can handle any data type from any ML framework. **Interactive dashboards** and powerful querying allow for deep experiment comparison. The **centralized model registry** manages model lineage and stage transitions (staging to production). **Native integrations** with virtually every major ML library and **RBAC** are critical for team-based, secure workflows in research and production environments.

sections.title: Use Cases
paragraphs:
**Use Antigravity if you are:** A software developer, startup, or agency building web applications, prototypes, or automation scripts. It's ideal for rapidly generating code from designs, automating browser-based tasks, or tackling complex coding projects where multiple specialized AI assistants would be beneficial. It suits those who want an all-in-one, AI-native coding environment and are comfortable with cutting-edge, evolving tools.

**Use Neptune if you are:** A data scientist, ML engineer, or research team training, fine-tuning, or evaluating machine learning models—especially large language or foundation models. It is essential for organizations that need to track hundreds of experiments, ensure reproducibility, compare model versions rigorously, and maintain a governed registry of models moving to production. It is the backbone for professional, collaborative ML workflows.

sections.title: Pros & Cons
paragraphs: **Antigravity Pros:** Completely free (preview); Revolutionary multi-agent collaboration for complex tasks; All-in-one IDE with integrated browser automation; Supports latest AI models (Gemini 3 Pro, Claude 4.5); Lowers barrier to advanced AI-assisted coding. **Antigravity Cons:** Still in preview, long-term viability and pricing unknown; Niche focused on coding/automation, not general AI tasks; May have a steeper learning curve for its novel multi-agent paradigm; Dependent on the stability and performance of underlying LLM APIs.

**Neptune Pros:** Industry-standard, mature MLOps platform; Extremely flexible metadata system adaptable to any workflow; Excellent integrations across the ML stack; Powerful collaboration and governance features for teams; Critical for reproducibility and model lifecycle management. **Neptune Cons:** Freemium model, can become costly for large teams/heavy usage; Steeper initial setup and conceptual overhead for simple projects; Focused solely on tracking/managing experiments, not on generating code or models itself.

verdict:
The choice between Antigravity and Neptune in 2025 is unequivocally defined by your primary role: are you a **builder** or a **scientist**?

For **software developers, web developers, and prototyping teams**, Antigravity represents a seismic shift in productivity. Its free access, combined with the unparalleled power of multi-agent AI collaboration, makes it an irresistible tool for accelerating development cycles, automating tedious tasks, and exploring complex coding projects with AI co-pilots. If your work revolves around writing code, building interfaces, and creating functional software, Antigravity is the definitive, forward-looking choice. The recommendation is strong, with the caveat that users should be prepared for the evolving nature of a preview-stage tool.

For **data scientists, ML engineers, and research organizations**, Neptune remains an indispensable, non-negotiable component of a professional ML stack. No other tool in this comparison provides the depth of experiment tracking, model governance, and team collaboration required for rigorous, reproducible machine learning at scale. Its flexibility and integrations make it the central hub for the entire model lifecycle. If your work involves training models, tuning hyperparameters, and managing model deployments, Neptune is the essential, enterprise-ready selection.

Ultimately, these tools are not direct competitors but powerful allies in different domains. A comprehensive AI-driven engineering team in 2025 might very well use **both**: Antigravity to rapidly build and iterate on application code and ML pipelines, and Neptune to meticulously track, compare, and manage the models and experiments that power those applications. For most users, however, the decision is clear-cut based on their core workflow. Choose Antigravity to create with AI; choose Neptune to manage and understand AI.

faqs.question: Can Antigravity be used for machine learning model development?
faqs.answer: Antigravity is primarily an AI-powered code editor and IDE. While you could certainly use it to write Python scripts for data science or ML (and it has Git integration), it lacks the specialized features for experiment tracking, metric logging, and model versioning that define MLOps platforms like Neptune. It is better suited for building the application or service that *uses* an ML model, rather than for the iterative training, evaluation, and management of the model itself. For end-to-end ML project management, Neptune is the appropriate tool.

faqs.question: Is Neptune suitable for individual developers or small projects?
faqs.answer: Yes, Neptune offers a free tier that is perfectly suitable for individual developers, students, or small projects. This allows you to log experiments, track metrics, and use the model registry on a smaller scale. However, its true power and cost structure are optimized for teams and large-scale experimentation. For an individual working on a simple model, the free tier is excellent. If you are a solo developer focused on general application coding (not ML), a tool like Antigravity would likely provide more direct value.
